Mass. G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Under Mass. G.L. c. 208, �������������������������������������������������������������, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the last order, and that the proposed modification is in the childs best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Mass. G.L. c. 208, ��������������������������������� and G.L. c. 209C, ��������������������������������� (as to divorces and custody modifications) and G.L. c. 209C, ������������������������ (as to custody determinations involving parents of minor children), as interpreted by *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Mass. G.L. c. 208, §28 (as to divorces and custody modifications) and G.L. c. 209C, §20 (as to custody determinations involving parents of minor children), as interpreted by *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 for divorce/custody modifications and custody determinations involving parents of minor children. Yannas deals with standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and best‑interests analysis in an already‑filed divorce action; it does not discuss subject matter or personal jurisdiction, nor does it interpret § 28 or § 20. Thus, this opinion does not provide authority for the jurisdictional proposition claimed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…"}

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Mass. G.L. c. 208, §28 (as to divorces and custody modifications) and G.L. c. 209C, §20 (as to custody determinations involving parents of minor children), as interpreted by *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard concerns the substantive standard for awarding custody in a divorce—i.e., application of the ‘best interests of the child’ and the need for adequate findings—not whether the Massachusetts courts have subject-matter or personal jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, §28 or G.L. c. 209C, §20. It does not analyze jurisdictional prerequisites or statutory bases for custody or modification proceedings. Thus, it does not provide authority for the jurisdictional proposition for which it is cited.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "We are not satisfied that the portion of the judgment of divorce nisi awarding custody of the parties’ minor child to the wife can be sustained without further findings. In awarding custody to the wife the judge seems not to have applied the appropriate criteria. See G. L. c. 208, § 31. ... This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed."

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a76.proposition: See G.L. c. 209C, §6, and *Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).

*Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).proposition: See G.L. c. 209C, §6, and *Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).
*Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).case_name: Roberts v. Southwestern Bell Mobile Systems, Inc.
*Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).support_reasoning: The quoted decision is not Santos v. Santos, 429 Mass. 490 (1999), but a zoning/Telecommunications Act case involving Southwestern Bell and Littleton. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 209C, § 6 (which concerns paternity/child support for children born out of wedlock) and in fact does not mention c. 209C at all. Therefore it cannot support any proposition that relies on G.L. c. 209C, § 6 or on the actual Santos v. Santos domestic relations decision.
*Santos v. Santos*, 429 Mass. 490 (1999).relevant_excerpt: Subject to these enumerated constraints, the TCA recognizes and protects local autonomy regarding PWS facility placement. Congress was explicit that the TCA does not preempt State and local authority with respect to any zoning and land use issues pertaining to PWS facilities, other than as delineated in § 332(c)(7) of the TCA. See 47 U.S.C. § 332(c)(7)(A). At issue in this case is whether the TCA requirement of local zoning authorities that any decision “to deny” a request to construct a cellular facility “be in writing and supported by substantial evidence contained in a written record,” 47 U.S.C. § 332(c)(7)(B)(iii), preempts, under the supremacy clause of the United States Constitution, de novo judicial review of all local zoning authority decisions pursuant to G. L. c. 40A, § 17.

*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: *Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009) (modification appropriate where circumstances materially change affecting child’s welfare).
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The case is centrally about modification of alimony, not child-related orders. While it reiterates the general rule that modification of alimony or child support requires a material change in circumstances, the facts and holding concern changes in the payor spouse’s retirement and the recipient spouse’s employment, not the child’s welfare. Thus, using Pierce as authority specifically for ‘modification appropriate where circumstances materially change affecting child’s welfare’ misstates its scope; it supports the broader material-change standard, but not the child-welfare-focused proposition.
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

*Schutzbank v. Schutzbank*, 76 Mass. App.proposition: *Schutzbank v. Schutzbank*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 827 (2010) (long-distance relocation requiring modification).
*Schutzbank v. Schutzbank*, 76 Mass. App.case_name: Global Investors Agent Corp. v. National Fire Insurance
*Schutzbank v. Schutzbank*, 76 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is an insurance coverage / duty-to-defend case (Gold v. National Fire/CNA) and does not involve family law, custody, or relocation issues. Nothing in the decision concerns long-distance relocation or modification of a custody order. Thus, citing Schutzbank v. Schutzbank, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 827 (2010), for a proposition about long-distance relocation requiring modification is inaccurate based on this text.
*Schutzbank v. Schutzbank*, 76 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: This case stems from a dispute concerning the defendant insurers’ duty to defend the plaintiffs against counterclaims resulting from an underlying action initiated by the plaintiffs in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine (Maine litigation). The Maine litigation settled in mediation prior to the defendants’ providing coverage, and the plaintiffs brought suit against the defendants in Massachusetts, alleging breach of contract and breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing for failing to defend them in the Maine litigation.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (relocation affecting child’s school schedule warrants reassessment of parenting time).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is about removal from the Commonwealth and whether that relocation justified a change in physical custody; it does not state that relocation affecting a child’s school schedule, by itself, warrants reassessment or modification of parenting time. In fact, the court criticizes a temporary custody change that altered the weekday schedule and school location when it was based solely on the relocation request, holding that such an order ‘should not have been made’ absent the statutory showing of harm. Thus, the opinion undermines, rather than supports, the claimed proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This was a change in custody during the pendency of a complaint for modification of a prior custody order, and must therefore have been based on ‘specific findings of fact . . . which clearly demonstrate the injury, harm or damage that might reasonably be expected to occur if relief pending a judgment of modification is not granted.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28A. The record reflects no reason for the order changing custody other than the mother’s motion to remove the child to Rhode Island. The order should not have been made.”

*White v. LaBay*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (.proposition: *White v. LaBay*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (2010) (child’s best interests are paramount in modification proceedings).
*White v. LaBay*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts medical malpractice/tribunal case involving an adult decedent and has nothing to do with family law, custody, or modification proceedings. It does not mention the best interests of the child standard or discuss modification proceedings at all. Citing this case for the proposition that a child’s best interests are paramount in modification proceedings is incorrect and misleading.
*White v. LaBay*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (.relevant_excerpt: Pursuant to G. L. c. 231, § 60B, the Superior Court convened a medical malpractice tribunal. Prior to the tribunal proceeding, the plaintiff submitted her offer of proof as the statute requires. After hearing arguments, the tribunal issued reports relative to each defendant... [T]he tribunal determined that the evidence presented was not sufficient... the complaint was dismissed on the defendant’s motion, and a separate and final judgment entered in her favor.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (court must consider stability, child’s routines, and continuity).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court explicitly ties the statutory ‘best interests’ analysis under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) to preserving stability and continuity, warning against unnecessarily disrupting satisfactory existing arrangements. It emphasizes that maintaining the child’s current placement and status quo, where possible, is ordinarily in the child’s best interests, and that stability itself is of ‘enormous benefit’—all of which directly encompass considering the child’s routines and continuity. Thus the case is proper authority for the proposition that the court must consider stability, the child’s routines, and continuity in custody decisions.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “These efforts also reflect the view that it is in the ‘best interests of the child’ to preserve the current placement with a parent, if it is a satisfactory one, and that stability and continuity with the child’s primary caregiver is itself an important factor in a child’s successful upbringing. … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (judicial focus remains on child’s best interests, not parental convenience).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly and explicitly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the governing standard for removal is the children’s best interests, and it emphasizes that this standard is grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the child. The court further notes that a relocating joint custodian must show that relocation is in the child’s best interests, “and not merely desired by the moving parent,” reflecting that parental convenience is subordinate to the child-focused inquiry. The holding applies that standard to deny removal based on impacts on the children, not on the mother’s preferences.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.… ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … [A parent with] true joint physical custody proposing a move should be required to prove that [relocation] is in the best interest of the child, and not merely desired by the moving parent.”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the dispute and the review standard in terms of the child’s “best interests” and rejects presumptions in favor of either the agency’s plan, the parents’ nomination, the current foster placement, or sibling co-placement. Instead, it emphasizes a flexible, fact‑specific inquiry focused on which placement will best meet this particular child’s developmental, emotional, and long‑term needs. That analysis is quintessentially child-centered rather than adult- or rights-centered, so the case supports the proposition that it emphasizes child-centered criteria.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child, not to afford any particular weight to either plan… [T]he best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one,’ and the weight to be accorded its several considerations… will vary with the circumstances.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a731.proposition: G.L. c. 208, §31 (defining shared custody and best-interest factors).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a730.proposition: G.L. c. 208, §30 (removal statute, relevant by analogy to relocations across jurisdictions).
